moves.1. d4: Hi everyone.  This is the first of two losses against chesstico.  In both of these I think my endgame technique was found lacking.  The purpose of the annotations is to ask the question: how?  So I may skip a bit of the earlier stages.
moves.4. Bg5 Be7 5. Nf3 O-O 6. e3 b6 7. Bd3 Bb: So far the game has been fairly uninteresting: not many tactical melees but Black has the advantage of only two pawn islands vs White's three, including the isolani on c4.  I probably made a mistake in getting here ...
moves.24. g3 Qc7 25. Qd4 f6 26. f3 Kf7 27. e4: Perhaps I shouldn't have allowed the Q swap here but I felt that the more advanced position of my king would give me an advantage.
moves.30... Kd6: Black seizes the opposition.  Now who has the more pawn moves to either keep it or snatch it away?
moves.31. a3 a6 32. a4 e5+: I think I should have tried to prevent this, if at all possible.  So perhaps I should have tried for f4 and e5 before advancing my a-pawn but I don't think I could actually have prevented it after 30.... Kd6
moves.33. Kc3: Perhaps 33. Kd3 would have left me the opportunity to play Kc3 at a later stage.
moves.33... Kc5 34. h3 g6 35. f4 g5 36. fxg5: I couldn't just let Black take on f4, so I had to either take on e5 or g5 or advance to f5.  I think that would have lead straight to a draw.  Taking on e5 would have left the smae configuration as taking on g5.
moves.36... fxg5 37. g4: Again, I don't think it would have made any difference which pawn I moved: 37. h4 gxh4 38. gxh4 h5 and White's K has to cede ground to Black's K: 39. Ke3 Kb4 wins the a-pawn.  39. Kb3 Kd4 wins the e-pawn.  This seems to confirm that 33. Kc3 was the losing move.

gameName: League division D1- an end-game lesson
